title: Prime Minister and Anonymous Messages
summary: This article talks about a problem in the UK government. Some people are sending secret messages to the media about the Prime Minister, Sir Keir Starmer. Ed Miliband and Wes Streeting, who are important politicians, are asking the Prime Minister to do something about these messages. They think these messages might be trying to challenge the Prime Minister's leadership. Sir Keir Starmer says he is sure that these messages did not come from his office at 10 Downing Street. This is important because it shows that there might be some disagreements among politicians, and they need to work together to solve problems.

keywords.explanation: the leader of the government in a country
when someone does not give their name
short reports or messages given to people
being in charge of a group or country
newspapers, TV, and websites that share news
to question or try to take over someone's position
said something is true to make someone feel sure
doing something to fix a problem

questions.question: Who is the Prime Minister in this article?
What are Ed Miliband and Wes Streeting asking the Prime Minister to do?
Where did Sir Keir Starmer say the briefings did not come from?
Why are the briefings a problem?
What does 'assured' mean in this article?

background_read: In the UK, the Prime Minister is the leader of the government and lives at 10 Downing Street. Sometimes, people in politics send secret messages to the media to share information without saying who they are. This can cause problems if it challenges the leader. Ed Miliband and Wes Streeting are politicians who want the Prime Minister to stop these messages to keep the government working well.
Article_Structure: WHO: Sir Keir Starmer, Ed Miliband, Wes Streeting, and anonymous people
WHAT: Anonymous briefings to the media about challenging the Prime Minister's leadership
WHERE: In the UK, specifically at 10 Downing Street
WHY: To address disagreements and maintain stable leadership

perspectives.description: Sir Keir Starmer believes the briefings did not come from his office and wants to assure everyone.
Ed Miliband and Wes Streeting think the Prime Minister should take action to stop the briefings.
